title: Fix Missing Tooltip and Unresponsive Chat History Icon When No Active Chat Session Exists
body:
Type: Bug Bug Description: When there is no active chat session in GitHub Copilot, the chat history icon lacks a tooltip on hover and does not respond to clicks, confusing users about its functionality. After starting a session, a "new chat" icon appears, and the chat history icon becomes responsive. title: Add syntax supporting extensions.json's recommendations versioning
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Summary:
Add support for specifying exact extension versions in _.vscode/extensions.json_ recommendations to ensure consistency, especially for legacy projects.

Proposed solution:
Add to the _extensions.json_ schema support for extended notation.

Current syntax :
```
{
  "recommendations": [
    "Dart-Code.dart-code",
    "ms-python.python"
  ]
}
```

Proposed syntax:
```
{
  "recommendations": [
    {
      "id": "Dart-Code.dart-code",
      "version": "3.222.1"
    },
    "esbenp.prettier-vscode"  // Mixed syntax support - takes the latest by default
  ]
}

```

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version:
```shell
1.104.0
f220831ea2d946c0dcb0f3eaa480eb435a2c1260
x64
```
- OS Version: 
```shell
Windows 11 Version 23H2
Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.22631.5768]
```
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Ensure all `$PROFILE`s are empty
2. `Get-ChildItem -p` + `ctrl` + `spacebar`
3. Letter "a" is typed

#### Workaround
Run the below after shell has loaded. Or add to your `$PROFILE`. Bonus points to check `$env:TERM_PROGRAM -eq 'vscode'`.
```pwsh
Set-PSReadLineKeyHandler -Chord 'F12,a' -Function MenuComplete
```

title: Proposal: Unify Search with File Explorer and Enhance Workflow via Terminal Integration
body:
Title

Proposal: Unify Search with File Explorer and Enhance Workflow via Terminal Integration

Description

Currently, VS Code separates the File Explorer and the Search views, which increases the number of panels and reduces the available editor space. I suggest unifying them to create a more lightweight and streamlined workflow, while keeping strong functionality.

Proposal

Search Bar in File Explorer

Place a search/filter bar above the File Explorer.

Example:

>$browser: -Filter ./xx/xxx/*.cs → File Explorer only shows the filtered files.

If the filter is empty, all files are shown again.

Command-Driven File Operations

Allow command-style inputs to trigger actions:

Example: >$browser: -Open ./xx/xxx.ps1, ../xxx/xx.ps1 → directly open specific files.

Terminal Integration

PowerShell, bash, or other terminals can participate in VS Code’s workflow.

Benefits:

Do more without leaving the keyboard.

Reduce window fragmentation and unnecessary context switching.

Reuse File Explorer for multiple purposes.

Keep VS Code lightweight while still powerful.

Maximize editor space by reducing the number of side views.

Motivation

Prevent VS Code from becoming bloated with too many separate views.

Maintain a lightweight, fast, and professional editing experience.

Empower advanced users who prefer terminal-driven workflows.

title: Copilot Agent stop button
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Often you see Copilot Agent doing stupid things and there is no way to stop it, you can only watch as disaster gets worse. It would be great if you could halt whatever Agent is doing, and perhaps then let it continue with some better instructions.

title: Feature Request: Allow choosing which terminal Copilot should use when executing suggested commands
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
## Description  
Currently, when Copilot suggests executing a command, the behavior of where the command gets executed is inconsistent. Sometimes it runs in an existing terminal (which may already be running another process, causing it to be interrupted), and other times it spawns a new terminal.  

This randomness can be disruptive, especially when important processes are running in specific terminals.  

## Proposed Solution  
- Provide an option to configure or select which terminal Copilot should use when running a suggested command.  
- Add the ability to explicitly choose:  
  - A specific existing terminal.  
  - A newly created terminal.  
- Ideally, this selection could be part of the workflow when Copilot suggests the command, or configurable as a default setting.  

## Benefits  
- Prevents accidental interruption of running processes.  
- Gives users more control and predictability.  
- Improves developer workflow by making command execution more reliable.  

---

Thank you for considering this accessibility and productivity enhancement for VS Code users!

title: Iteration Plan for September 2025

labels.name: iteration-plan
labels.description: VS Code - Upcoming iteration plan

body:
This plan captures our work in **September 2025**. This is a 4-week iteration. We will ship in **early October**. It is a continuation of the August plan without any additions. Although a 4-week iteration, we'll have only 1 dev week. The second week is reserved for planning and engineering conversations.

## Endgame
- **September 29, 2025**: Endgame begins
- **October 3, 2025**: Endgame done

The endgame details for this iteration are tracked [here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues?q=is%3Aissue+label%3Aendgame-plan+milestone%3A%22September+2025%22).

| :red_circle:         | missing issue reference                           |

title: Terminal auto-approve backend does not reliably apply regex/wildcard rules, requiring excessive literal command line approvals

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
Observed behavior:
When using the VS Code 'chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove' setting, even with a global regex rule (e.g. '/.*/': true), many terminal commands only get auto-approved if their full literal command line is explicitly listed. This results in a proliferation of literal command line approvals, despite having comprehensive regex and wildcard rules.

Expected behavior:
Regex and wildcard rules should reliably match and auto-approve all relevant terminal commands, minimizing the need for literal command line approvals.

Impact:
- Reduces maintainability and clarity of settings
- Indicates a bug or limitation in the backend matching logic for terminal command approval
- Hinders full agent autonomy and automation

Steps to reproduce:
1. Set 'chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove' to { '/.*/': true } in settings.json (see attached context).
2. Attempt to run a variety of terminal commands via agent/extension automation.
3. Observe that some commands are only auto-approved if their full literal command line is added, not via regex/wildcard.

Recommendation:
Investigate and fix the backend matching logic so that regex and wildcard rules are reliably applied to all terminal commands, eliminating the need for literal command line approvals. This will improve maintainability and enable full agent autonomy.

Context:
See settings.json and recent agent/user discussion for details.

title: Organize entries in settings.json into section and allow sorting
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I encountered `Unable to write into user settings.` recently in VS Code in macOS environment. I spent some time but couldn't find the issues and fix it so I ended up backing up the `settings.json` in `/Users/<username>/Library/Application Support/Code/User` folder and re-create the `settings.json` from scratch.

After re-configure the entries in the new `settings.json` file awhich looks around 80% like my original `settings.json` (I decided to remove some unused or seldom use entries), then I decided to manually sort the entries in alphabetic order and organize them into sections for my easy reference.

So I suggest the enhance the `settings.json` as follows:

1. Organize the entries in `settings.json` into section as follows:

```
{
    // a
    <entries that start with a>
    // b
    <entries that start with b>
    // c
    <entries that start with c>
    // ....
    // z
    <entries that start with z>
}
```

2. Allow sorting of entries in the `settings.json`

Since any new entries added to the `settings.json` will be appended to the end. When there are lot of entries, finding the right entries quickly require using search functon. Besides, it is difficult to see similar entries unless the user manually relocate the entries and put them together.

3. keep entries in `settings.json` even after the values were reverted to the default value instead of removing them from `settings.json`

Sample of the proposed `settings.json` as follows:


```
{
    // a
    "application.shellEnvironmentResolutionTimeout": 120,
    // c
    "css.autoValidation": "Always",
    // d
    "dart.flutterSdkPath": "....",
    // e
    "editor.autoIndentOnPaste": true,
    "editor.defaultFormatter": null,
    "editor.guides.bracketPairs": true,
    "editor.fontFamily": "FiraCode-Retina",
    "editor.fontLigatures": true,
    "editor.fontWeight": "400",
    "editor.linkedEditing": true,
    "editor.minimap.enabled": false,
    "editor.mouseWheelZoom": true,
    "editor.renderWhitespace": "all",
    // f
    "files.autoSave": "afterDelay",
    "files.defaultLanguage": "plaintext",
    "files.dialog.defaultPath": "...",
    "files.associations": {
        "*.cpp": "cpp",
        "*.cs": "csharp",
        "*.js": "javascript",
        "*.html": "html",
        "*.py": "python",
        "*.ts": "typescript",
        "*.txt": "plaintext",
    },
    // g
    "git.autofetch": true,
    "git.openRepositoryInParentFolders": "never",
    "github.copilot.nextEditSuggestions.enabled": true,
    "geminicodeassist.project": "trusty-legend-453808-c4",
    // n
    "nextbasic.cspect": "...",
    "nextbasic.cspectOptions": "-w6 -vsync -s28 -60 -tv -basickeys -zxnext -nextrom",
    "nextbasic.nextImagePath": "...",
    // o
    "omnisharp.dotNetCliPaths": [
        "..."
    ],
    "omnisharp.sdkPath": "...",
    "omnisharp.dotnetPath": "...",
    "omnisharp.sdkIncludePrereleases": false,
    // p
    "python.analysis.aiCodeActions": {     
        "enabled": true,
        "generateDocstring": true,
        "generateTests": true,
        "explainCode": true,
        "optimizeImports": true,
        "fixPEP8": true,
        "refactor": true,
        "convertFunctionToLambda": false,
        "convertLambdaToNamedFunction": false,
        "enable": true,
        "suggestionsMode": "Detailed",
        "implementAbstractClasses": true,
        "generateSymbol": true,
        "convertFormatString": true
    },
    "python.analysis.autoFormatStrings": true,
    "python.analysis.autoImportCompletions": true,
    "python.analysis.gotoDefinitionInStringLiteral": false,
    "python.analysis.include": [
        "${workspaceFolder}/**/*.py",
        "${workspaceFolder}/**/*.ipynb"
    ],
    "python.analysis.typeCheckingMode": "standard",
    "python.createEnvironment.contentButton": "show",
    "python.defaultInterpreterPath": "...",
    "python.languageServer": "Pylance",
    "python.terminal.activateEnvInCurrentTerminal": true,
    "python.terminal.focusAfterLaunch": true,
    "python.terminal.executeInFileDir": true,
    "python.venvPath": "~/.pyenv",
    // s
    "security.workspace.trust.untrustedFiles": "open",
    // t
    "terminal.integrated.fontFamily": "MesloLGS NF",
    "terminal.integrated.cwd": "",
    // u
    "update.showReleaseNotes": false,
    // w
    "window.restoreWindows": "preserve",
    "window.zoomLevel": 1,
    "workbench.colorCustomizations": {},
    "workbench.colorTheme": "One Dark Modern",
    "workbench.settings.useSplitJSON": false,
    "workbench.startupEditor": "none",
}
```

Note that "..." refers to a valid path.


Scenario 1:

- If the user add a new entries that start with "k" (just as an example), and VS Code add the entry to the end of `settings.json` like this.

```
{
    .
    .
    .
    // g
    "git.autofetch": true,
    "git.openRepositoryInParentFolders": "never",
    "github.copilot.nextEditSuggestions.enabled": true,
    "geminicodeassist.project": "trusty-legend-453808-c4",
    // n
    "nextbasic.cspect": "...",
    "nextbasic.cspectOptions": "-w6 -vsync -s28 -60 -tv -basickeys -zxnext -nextrom",
    "nextbasic.nextImagePath": "...",
    .
    .
    .
    "<entries that start with k>": <value>,
}
```

VS Code add a function to allow user to sort the entries in alphabetic order and if it is also the only entry that starts with k, then add the comment `// k` above the entry that start with k like this:

```
{
    .
    .
    .
    // g
    "git.autofetch": true,
    "git.openRepositoryInParentFolders": "never",
    "github.copilot.nextEditSuggestions.enabled": true,
    "geminicodeassist.project": "trusty-legend-453808-c4",
    // k
    "<entry that start with k>": <value>,
    // n
    "nextbasic.cspect": "...",
    "nextbasic.cspectOptions": "-w6 -vsync -s28 -60 -tv -basickeys -zxnext -nextrom",
    "nextbasic.nextImagePath": "...",
    .
    .
    .
}
```

Scenario 2:

- If the user add another entry which also start with k, and VS Code add the entry to the end of `settings.json` again but user can sort the entries in the `settings.json` such that both entries that start with k will be sorted in alphabetic order as follows:

```
{
    .
    .
    .
    // g
    "git.autofetch": true,
    "git.openRepositoryInParentFolders": "never",
    "github.copilot.nextEditSuggestions.enabled": true,
    "geminicodeassist.project": "trusty-legend-453808-c4",
    // k
    "<first entry that start with k>": <value>,
    "<second entry that start with k>": <value>,
    // n
    "nextbasic.cspect": "...",
    "nextbasic.cspectOptions": "-w6 -vsync -s28 -60 -tv -basickeys -zxnext -nextrom",
    "nextbasic.nextImagePath": "...",
    .
    .
    .
}
```

Scenario 3:

- Assume the user change the entry `update.showReleaseNotes` from `false` to `true` and also assume that `true` is the default value. Instead of removing the  `update.showReleaseNotes` entry from `settings.json`, VS Code will update its value to `true` and add the comment to indicate that the value is the default value. 

Example:

```
{
    .
    .
    .
    // u
    "update.showReleaseNotes": true, // Default
    .
    .
    .
}
```

title: Feature Request: Native Text-to-Speech (TTS) Support in Copilot Chat for VS Code

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Summary:
Please add built-in text-to-speech (TTS) functionality to the Copilot Chat window in Visual Studio Code, allowing Copilot to automatically speak all AI-generated answers.

Use Case:
VS Code users—including those with visual impairments, multitaskers, or anyone who prefers listening—would benefit from having Copilot Chat responses read aloud automatically, without needing to manually select text or use external accessibility tools.

Requested Feature:

A setting in Copilot Chat for VS Code to enable automatic TTS for all AI answers.
User controls for voice selection, speech rate, and volume.
Options to pause, stop, or replay spoken responses.
Benefits:

Improves accessibility for visually impaired VS Code users.
Enhances productivity by enabling hands-free listening to Copilot’s responses.
Makes Copilot Chat in VS Code more inclusive and user-friendly.
Current Limitation:
No native TTS support exists in Copilot Chat for VS Code; users must rely on external tools or extensions, which may not integrate seamlessly.

Thank you for considering this accessibility and productivity enhancement for VS Code users!

title: Add setting that DISABLES the "The window is not responding" pop-up.
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I use experimental agentic builds in VScode which sometimes run very slowly... on VSCode.  They are working, and churning out responses, editing files, all that. They just do it slowly.  But, like, I am testing these models just on the backburner on crappy PC's on purpose for benchmarking.   

This effing pop-up is driving me nuts.  I just have to click "Keep Waiting" literally over 100 times a day.  My thing never crashes.  Please allow a setting to at least **INCREASE THE TIMEOUT?** or ideally **DISABLE COMPLETELY**.

PLEASE?! 

The problem is sometimes the pop-up will force a restart if I go too long without clicking "Keep Waiting", and the model is taking a long time.  


If it was not for these pop-ups, I would honestly be less stressed because I could send my inference, have the model tortoise its way to the finish line, and get my data while I am brewing my cuppa cappuccino or mixing up a vodka tonic.  
But I gotta babysit the thing to click "Keep Waiting"... over a hundred times per day.



Oh yes extension host resources matters not.  Whether I have only my extension for interacting with the models running alone or have 50 other extensions up, the pop-up will still appear.  


Edit: hmm.  I  might make a rust bin that just clicks the mouse in the same X, Y position if it ever detects the the pop-up in the meantime.  But that is not 100% reliable.  Thanks for the triage.

  This encryption error might affect VS Code's ability to store/retrieve sensitive data like authentication tokens or passwords securely.

title: [bug] auto-approval causing chat to hang after terminal execution
body: Ever since the release on the 11th, the chat has no longer been able to run commands in the terminal. It asks for the new auto-approval feature, click allow, see the terminal run, but then the chat hangs indefinitely with the command spinning. body:
Folding ranges will sometimes break when pasting over Folded ranges
the ranges will appear in the wrong location/don't show up at all
`editor.removeManualFoldingRanges` does not fix it
nor does changing the language and sometimes even reloading
still happens even with `"editor.foldingStrategy": "indentation"`

found some solid repo steps
happens when pasting text over already recursively collapsed text
doesn't have to be JSON, happens in plaintext and TypeScript etc as well

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open large file with many foldings
  https://github.com/RedCMD/TmLanguage-Syntax-Highlighter/blob/main/syntaxes/regex.tmLanguage.json
3. recursively collapse most of the file (with middle-click/scroll-click/button 3)
4. paste a different large file over top
  https://github.com/RedCMD/redcmd.rascal-syntax-highlighter/blob/master/syntaxes/rascal.tmLanguage.json
6. witness broken foldings left behind

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/dfcc4125-d488-41fd-a503-33ee091b174d



Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0
- OS Version: Windows 11

title: Co-pilot kills long builds by trying to run get-item
body:
Type: Bug build llama.cpp, watch claude decide it REALLY needs to check the directory contents in the same terminal right now... cd external\llama.cpp\build && cmake --build . --config Debug Let me check the full output to see if the build completed: Checked background terminal output Great! The build is proceeding well. I can see it's creating the DLLs and LIB files we need. title: Feature request: when using remote tunnel, recognize existing remote workspace
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
currently the chat history is only available on the client machine, when i have access to the server, i won't be able to resume the chat. 
I have tried `chat:export` this works fine, but when doing `chat:import`, it only displays a blank editor tab.
<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
when using remote tunnel, vscode should recognize the remote workspace on the dir, use the remote instance of github copilot and store the chat on the remote machine for continuity.

Note this is different from [vscode-copilot-release](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-release) #991, it has nothing to do with syncing across devices. it shouldn't store chat history in the client machine in the first place in this scenario.

title: Add setting to include 'Co-authored-by:' commit trailer when AI codegen was used

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: git
labels.description: GIT issues

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I'd like to be able to automatically indicate that some of the code I'm including in a commit was generated by AI. Since vscode is tracking that metadata, it would be useful to have a setting (or set of settings) that allow:

- enabling automatic inclusion of `Co-authored-by:` git trailer when AI codegen is used (for some definition of AI codegen)
- specifying which model(s) were used for the code generation as part of the author attribution
- setting thresholds for inclusion (for tab-completion? for copilot "edit"? for copilot "agent"?)

title: Agent stuck in a loop trying to summarize a fresh conversation
body:
Type: Bug I gave the agent this prompt: ```markdown According to the [documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/logic-apps/edit-app-settings-host-settings?tabs=azure-portal),I need to set `Runtime.Backend.HttpWebhookOperation.RequestTimeout` to be `00:10:00` (10 minutes) for #sym:imagePipelineWorkflow to wait for longer. I don't see a way of setting that in the [bicep documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/templates/microsoft.logic/workflows?pivots=deployment-language-bicep). Can you help me make the change? ``` Without any previous mesages in the chat, and it immediately started trying to summarize a non-existant conversation: ``` Read todo list Read todo list Summarized conversation history Read todo list Summarized conversation history Read todo list Summarized conversation history Created 3 todos Summarized conversation history Read todo list Summarized conversation history Read todo list Summarized conversation history ``` The 3 TODOs created are completely unrelated to the prompt. I have the agent's model set to `Auto`, and it was trying to use `GPT-4o mini`. Retrying the same prompt with `GPT-5 mini` successfully started the process. title: Horizontal scroll not working with trackpad on Mac M3
body:
Type: Bug I'm having a serious issue on my Mac M3 where the horizontal scrollbar simply doesn't appear in VS Code, even though I have it explicitly set to visible in my settings. This means I can't scroll horizontally at all - neither with trackpad gestures nor by clicking a scrollbar that should be there but isn't. When I write long lines of code that extend beyond the screen width, VS Code just cuts them off visually with no way to scroll to see the rest. I've double-checked my settings.json and confirmed that "editor.scrollbar.horizontal": "visible" is set, along with "editor.wordWrap": "off", but the horizontal scrollbar never shows up. This is completely breaking my workflow because I can't see long lines of code without manually breaking them, which I really don't want to do. The vertical scrollbar works fine, and this issue is specific to VS Code - other apps show horizontal scrollbars normally. Here's what I experience: 1. Verify in settings.json that I have: - "editor.scrollbar.horizontal": "visible" - "editor.wordWrap": "off" - "editor.scrollbar.horizontalScrollbarSize": 14 2. Create a new file and type a very long line that clearly exceeds the window width 3. Look at the bottom of the editor where the horizontal scrollbar should appear 4. Result: No horizontal scrollbar visible at all, line just gets cut off 5. Try any trackpad gesture - nothing works because there's no scrollbar to begin with The problem persists even with all extensions disabled. I can use keyboard shortcuts like Cmd+arrow keys to move around, but I have no visual indication of where I am in a long line, and no way to scroll smoothly. title: Poor RTL (Right-to-Left) and Mixed LTR/RTL Text Rendering in VS Code Chat and Editor
body:
Description:

Hello VS Code Team,

I am experiencing significant issues with the rendering of right-to-left (RTL) languages (such as Persian or Arabic) when mixed with English (left-to-right) words in both the editor and chat extensions. When a sentence contains both RTL and LTR words, the order of words becomes confusing and hard to read. For example, the English words often break the flow of the RTL sentence, making it very difficult to follow, especially when there are multiple English words in a single line.

I have tried all available RTL-related extensions, but none of them fully solve the problem. Copying the text to another editor is not a practical solution for daily work.

Expected behavior:

Proper support for RTL text and correct rendering of mixed RTL/LTR sentences, similar to how modern browsers or editors like Microsoft Word handle it.
Seamless reading experience for users who work with RTL languages and need to mix English terms in their code or documentation.
Steps to reproduce:

Write a sentence in Persian or Arabic and include several English words in the same line.
Observe the word order and how the sentence is rendered in the editor or chat.
Example:


این یک جمله تستی با کلمات English و VS Code و Copilot است.
Screenshot:
(Attach a screenshot if possible)

Please consider improving RTL and mixed text rendering in future releases. This feature is very important for many users around the world.

Thank you!

title: Don't require an editing session for "new chat" to work
body:
There have been some different issues causing chats to break and not have an editing session associated with the chat model. if "new chat" doesn't work in that state then there is no escape, so don't require it.
Fix #265669
